MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1977 TO 31ST MARCH, 1978



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [6th Allotted Day]

Column: 1424

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head O -

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin (Bedok): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head O be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead AAA 1004*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Cheong Yuen Chee, P. Govindaswamy, Ivan Baptist and Ch'ng Jit Koon).

    It is common knowledge, Sir, that the Housing and Development Board is the largest statutory body in the Republic. It has an annual budget approximating $1,000 million. It is also common knowledge that the HDB is ruler of more than half the population. As its building statistics go up, which is, of course, commendable, it becomes more and more powerful, "ruling" more and more

Column: 1425

people with each passing day. It is expected that by 1980, some 75% of the population will be living in high-rise flats, for it is an inexorable truth that high-rise living will be a way of life for most of us, whether we like it or not. Apart from the effective leadership, our political stability and economic progress, the HDB's successful housing programme has in many ways reflected the Republic's multifarious achievements.

    However, I must point out that as a consequence of all this success - a consequence that is rather disconcerting there appears to be a deterioration of administrative efficiency and effectiveness in the HDB. This is especially true in planning the provision of recreational facilities in housing estates in New Towns. I say this with all seriousness. It is a growing sore point which should be checked. A fully developed New Town can engender and stimulate the growth of a crop of urban problems. In years to come, these problems can assume insurmountable proportions unless there is the administrative skill, efficiency and effectiveness to stem the tide.

    It may be true that the Estate Area Office and the HDB Headquarters are monitoring the situation. But from what I have personally experienced over the past three months at Bedok New Town, there is a whole host of shortcomings. I do not mean to say that I am not getting the full cooperation of the officials concerned. Far from it. My relationship with the Estate Area Officer and his officials is, at the best of terms. They are even present at my monthly meet-the-people sessions or forums where they have to answer some of the queries made by the residents on matters pertaining to HDB policies. My complaints are more in the area of decision-making and prompt action in attending to problems or requests made either by the residents or through me. All important matters, Sir, have to be referred to the Headquarters in Maxwell Road. Strange as it may seem, but nevertheless true, matters and problems pertaining to Bedok New Town have to be referred to the Area Office in Marine Parade. Why, Sir? Because there is no Area Office in Bedok New Town. This is not so bad. In

Column: 1426

another New Town that I know, the residents have to travel quite a long distance to pay their rentals, etc. However, I am glad to hear that the plan to construct the new Area Office in Bedok New Town has been finalised and construction will start very soon and it is expected to be completed by early next year. My point is: why is the planning and construction of the Area Office not done simultaneously with the moving in of residents to avoid unnecessary inconvenience and grumblings from them?

    Secondly, Sir, for almost two years now, the children and the youths in Neighbourhood I of Bedok New Town have no playground or recreational facilities. They are thus forced to play in car parks, in the estate's by-roads, void decks, open spaces between blocks, and at the concrete concourse at the market and hawker food centre which causes annoyance to the residents. Yet there are five hectares of open space which is earmarked for a miniature park and recreational facilities. It is being planted with trees and one section has been fenced in with barbed wires. The barbed wires have been removed recently after the residents had made complaints through me and direct to the officers concerned.

    What is the rationale behind all this? I know why the HDB did this. They do not want the children and the youngsters to play in it. Could you imagine a population of 16,000 more than half of whom are young people, without a single place for them to play? I have made some suggestions to the Area Office as to how the problem of lack of playing facilities could be temporarily solved. I suggested to the officials concerned to remove some of the trees to somewhere else so that the children could play there temporarily until the open space was developed. But they had no authority to act as such matters could only be decided by the top officials at Maxwell Road. However, I am happy to inform the House that the Minister of State has recently announced in his reply to an Oral Question that the development of recreational facilities for Neighbourhood I would be carried out soon and that it is expected to be completed by early next year.

Column: 1427



    Sir, the Housing and Development Board is naturally primarily concerned with achieving targets to cut down the waiting period for applicants. This is accepted. But in the anxiety to meet targets of building flats, a lot of things tend to be overlooked in some areas. In the case of Neighbourhood I where the population is now concentrated, the general complaints that I receive from residents are the conspicuous absence or lack of playing grounds and recreational facilities, whereas the residents of Marine Parade who moved in at the same time as the Bedok New Town residents are enjoying all Sorts of facilities and amenities which are provided not only by the Housing and Development Board but also by the Singapore Sports Council and the Parks and Recreation Department of the Ministry of National Development.

    Sir, to avoid such situations which could easily lead to misinterpretations and grouses by disgruntled residents, would the Minister for National Development and Communications consider proposing to the HDB to delegate more powers to the Area Estate Officers who, in fact, come directly under the Estates Department, which is within the Estates and Land Division of the HDB, so that they can make decisions that are urgent and obvious without the time-consuming necessity of having to refer everything to Headquarters at Maxwell Road. If this is done, Sir, it will cut down a lot of the customary red-tape, bureaucractic muddle and much of the official arrogance that is sometimes experienced. It will lead to greater efficiency in the management of the housing estates.

    Sir, new towns like Bedok New Town, which may not be very large in terms of size, are nevertheless densely populated when the flats are fully occupied, and therefore concern the lives and livelihood of people from all walks of life. A fully developed New Town could house as many as a quarter of a million or more people in the Republic, and that is no mean figure, considering the Republic's total population of just over two million.

Column: 1428



    Finally, Sir, I would like to make this special request to the Minister in regard to planning and development of recreational facilities in Neighbourhood II of Bedok New Town. It might be an administrative oversight or bad planning on the part of HDB that in the case of residents of Neighbourhood I who had to wait almost two years before they could get their playgrounds and recreational facilities -

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, we have to import our livestock, particularly cattle, from neighbouring countries. We have been obtaining our beef requirements mainly from Australia and New Zealand at very high cost to the consumers. The recent agreement signed with Thailand to proceed with the joint project on cattle raising for export to Singapore is indeed a welcome move. May I ask the Minister whether this project includes the provision of veterinary services and abattoir facilities to our partners in Southern Thailand? Furthermore, whether there are any plans to start a similar project with other ASEAN countries, for instance, Indonesia? Finally, whether such a project will help to reduce the cost of such beef in Singapore?

2.45 p.m.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, members of the public are so confused as to which department is actually doing the day-to-day work relating to planning. The Development Control Division broke off from the Planning Department in 1974 and came under the wing of the Building Control Division of the PWD. Members of the public who need advice in planning matters have close contact with the Development Control Division rather than the Planning Department which only deals with the long term Master Plan. Since the Development Control Division is an important department in Singapore, dealing with the construction of

Column: 1429

buildings in the private sector, change of use, etc. its status should be upgraded as a Department on its own directly under the Ministry. Not enough publicity has been given to the public as to which department deals with Government projects or those from the statutory boards and which department deals with applications from the private sector. I have had many queries from the public on the confused state of affairs. Even some professional people do not seem to know that part of the Planning Department's work is done by the Development Control Division, where many Town Planners are employed. Since the Development Control Division is a very important department, it should be part and parcel of the Planning Department. It is senseless and illogical to split the two. They should be merged in the interest of expediency, efficiency, prestige and, last but not least, there will be less confusion among members of the public.

    Sometime in 1966 the Development Control Division was taken out of the Planning Department and put under the Chief Building Surveyor's Department. That caused utter confusion. In 1970, it was returned to the Planning Department. In 1974, the Development Control Division was taken out again and this time it was put under the Public Works Department. Why is there all this confusion? Would not the staff be also puzzled? It is about time things were put right once and for all.

    The Development Control Division's officers and planners are doing a good job by providing the day-to-day service to the public on planning problems and advice. This is the feedback which I got from members of the public who often approached me on planning matters.

    Sir, sometime ago the former Chief Planner resigned from the service and migrated to another country to take up a post there. Why is the post of Chief Planner still vacant? Are there no suitably qualified local town planners with experience to fill the post?

Column: 1430



    What is being done to upgrade the long service staff in this department who have reached the maximum of their salary scale? If something is not done to boost their morale and provide incentives, the experienced and dedicated ones may resign and go away to other countries, like the former Chief Planner.

    Sir, touching on urbanisation, I wonder what is the policy of the Building Control Division in granting permits for different lots of land. I have received a number of complaints that many adjacent lots of land have been granted permits with different conditions. For instance, the first lot of land is given a permit to put up an eight-storey building, whereas the adjacent lot is not even permitted to put up a six-storey building. There seems to be some sort of discrimination here. May I know what is the guideline?

    Finally, I have also received complaints from some people that the Building Control Division does not permit some homes to hold group prayers, and they give a lot of trouble to the occupants. Why cannot they allow the people to carry on their prayers? After all, they are not causing any problem to anyone. Could the Minister clarify this point?

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Sir, on the 21st March, 1975, in this House under your able guidance, I brought up the matter in regard to the deletion of certain clauses from the Sand and Granite Quarries Regulations, 1971, when the Ministry of National Development took over the enforcement of these Regulations from the Ministry of Labour and replaced the 1971 Regulations with the 1974 Regulations. I wanted to know why this was done as it clearly disadvantaged the workers' health due to the lessening of the dust control measures and the reduction of medical checks. Free silica, a dust pollutant, emitted from granite quarries, when inhaled, can cause a pulmonary disease, silicosis, which is a dreadful disease indeed; it is incurable, rendering the ones inflicted a painful and useless life resembling the living dead.

    In reply to my queries on the deletion, the Hon. Minister for Law and National

Column: 1431

Development said [Hansard, Vol. 34, 21st March, 1975. col. 785]:

    `The Member for Potong Pasir referred to the deletion of two important clauses in the Sand and Granite Quarries Regulations of 1974. There seems to be substance in what he says. I was not aware of the deletion of these two clauses. Perhaps there is good reason, but there does not appear to be. But I will look into these regulations and reinsert these two clauses if that should be done.'

    Again, on 24th November, 1976, the Member for Toa Payoh queried the deletion of certain clauses from the 1971 Regulations when the 1974 Regulations replaced them. The Minister for National Development and Communications in reply stated [Hansard, Vol. 35, 24th November, 1976, cols. 1071 and 1072]:

    'Sir, these Regulations were deleted because in drafting the 1974 Regulations, the Attorney-General had advised that it would be undesirable to duplicate provisions which already existed in some other legislation. The deleted Regulations are covered by the Factories Act. 1973.'

    However, Sir, the only regulations contained in the Factories Act deleted were Regulations 20, 21, 22 and 23 which I accept, and these were not the regulations that came under query by the Member for Toa Payoh. Regulations 11, 12, 13. 16, 17, 18 and 19 are the ones that must be included in the 1974 Regulations. These are the ones pertaining to dust control and health measures that, without which, could cause health problems not only for the workers but also the people living around the quarries, many of them squatters with no knowledge of the dangers. Due to the absence of these clauses dust levels from the HDB quarry in Mandai, for instance, continue to remain high. It is about time the Ministry took action to restore the Regulations to an effective state. I am sure the assistance of the Ministry of Labour's Industrial Health Department can be sought, for are they not Government experts on industrial health?

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru)(In Mandarin): Sir, what I would like to say mainly concerns the Housing and Developing Board. I reserve this for amendment (6)*. (See Col. 1476.)

Column: 1432



    The Minister for National Development and Communications (Mr Lim Kim San): Sir, I am glad that when the Member for Bedok mentioned that the Housing Board will be ruling quite a large proportion of the population of Singapore, he mentioned "ruling" within inverted commas. Let me assure him that the Housing and Development Board does not seek to rule the people of Singapore but seek to house the people of Singapore.

    I am a bit puzzled by his remarks. He said that there was no delegation of authority to the officers to make small decisions and yet he found them helpful, co-operative and prompt in taking action. If there had been no delegation of authority, the staff would be unable to take prompt action.

    Let me assure him that we know that the Housing Board is expanding and will soon be managing a very large proportion of dwellings in Singapore. In keeping with modern management methods, only important policy matters are decided in the HDB headquarters and, wherever possible, administrative and routine procedures are delegated to the local officials.

    To come to the planning of new towns. It would be ideal if we can at the same time provide all the facilities of a town as well as housing. Marine Parade has been quoted as an example where the residents are able to enjoy living in very good quality flats and at the same time have all the facilities available. It is the same with Bedok. Wherever possible, Sir, we would like to provide all the facilities at the same time but perhaps there may be some technical reasons for being unable to do so. Our first priority, of course, is to provide the housing, and here I think the Member is quite satisfied that an assurance has been given to him that the recreational facilities he seeks for Neighbourhood I will be completed very soon and work is going on in Neighbourhood II.

    In planning for a new town, there are certain basic principles. The town shall be self-contained. As far as possible, it should have a town centre, sports facilities, playing

Column: 1433

fields, parking areas. When the plan is being drawn up the Housing Board would normally consult with other Government agencies, such as the PWD, the Sports Council and even the bus company so that all the necessary amenities could be provided. Also from time to time we get feedbacks from residents, and MPs too, about shortages of certain requirements or a lack of facilities in some of the towns. Where the suggestions are useful they are adopted. Therefore, suggestions from MPs are always welcome when we are planning a new town. I think that should be sufficient answer or clarification for the Member for Bedok.

    The Prime Minister recently visited Thailand and concluded an agreement with the Thai Government. In that agreement, there is provision for a cattle project in a joint venture between the Marketing Organisation for Farmers of Thailand (MOF) and Singapore's Primary Industries Enterprises (PIE). This joint venture will enable our veterinary surgeons to participate in the management of cattle rearing in Thailand for export and it will also enable our veterinary surgeons to examine the cattle before export to Singapore to ensure that they do not suffer from any disease. So this project will give us an additional supply of cattle. Whether it will really help to lower the price of beef or not will depend upon a lot of factors.

3.00 p.m.

    But one would expect that with more avenues of supply, prices are likely to fall. But here, as I have said, it depends upon a lot of other things, for instance, transport cost and feed cost. But our purpose here is, of course, to try to find a new source of supply to Singapore. If we have more supplies available, prices would naturally fall. In addition, the MOF and the PIE have also formed a joint company, the Sing Thai Grains (Private) Limited, to promote the marketing of Thai agricultural produce in Singapore. Of course, where suitable joint ventures with other countries in this region are proposed, they will be welcome. We will join with other ASEAN countries in promoting joint ventures.

Column: 1434



    The Member for Anson has a very good insight into what is going on in the Planning Department in the Ministry of National Development. But to put matters straight, let me first say that the Planning Department is concerned with long-term and medium-term planning. It is concerned with the Master Plan. In other words, the Planning Department is concerned with the use of land in Singapore, subdividing them into zones for certain specific uses. The Development Control Division is the enforcing department. In other words, it sees to it that where a building construction is being undertaken, it should conform to the Master Plan or to the plan drawn up by the Planning Department. These are the different roles. The Planning Department will deal with applications for construction from statutory bodies and Government departments, whereas the Development Control Division will deal with applications for construction from the private sector and from the citizens.

    I am a little surprised that the Member should mention that there is confusion among members of the public as to the roles these two departments are playing. This arrangement was set up in 1972, that is, four years ago, and I do not expect members of the public, especially the architects who are professionals in their own right to be confused over this division of labour. He has said that the BCD is performing a very important role because it enforces planning control, In a small island like Singapore it is imperative that there should be careful use and allocation of land, otherwise we will have residential areas side by side with factories and the whole place will be polluted. The BCD is playing an important role and, as such, he has suggested that it should be upgraded to a department. At the same time, he has suggested that it should be a part of the Planning Department. I think there is a bit of confusion. But no matter what it is, I think what he is trying to stress is the importance of planning control in Singapore. I fully agree with that because it should be the only authority to see how construction should be undertaken.

    He is a bit worried about opportunities for promotion in the department itself. Like most

Column: 1435

Government departments, there are ample opportunities for good officers to be promoted. We have a very unbiased and a very wise body consisting of private members who sit on a promotion board for civil servants, namely, the Public Service Commission. As hon. Members know, there is a new Government policy whereby good officers are promoted in spite of the fact that there are no posts. They are promoted on their own merit without having to wait for the creation of a post. Therefore, there are very good opportunities for promotion for very good officers in the Planning Department as well as in other Government departments.

    To come to the specific case of the Chief Planner. The Chief Planner was dismissed from service in 1973. As a result of that, a division took place between the Planning Division and the Development Control Division. At one time there were quite a lot of irregularities and laxity in enforcing development control. That was one of the reasons why probably the Chief Planner was dismissed. Then the Deputy Planner left us for greener fields abroad. At the moment we have an acting Chief Planner, and when he will be promoted will depend upon a promotion exercise by the Public Service Commission.

    He has mentioned about inconsistency in allowing development between adjacent parcels of land. Normally it is unlikely that there will be much difference between development allowed on adjacent pieces of land. But, of course, there must be some difference. The adjacent pieces of land may be of different shape or they may be of irregular shapes. They may be smaller or bigger. But on the whole it depends on the zoning. If they are in an industrial zone and the pieces of land are side by side, planning for industrial use is allowed and the plot ratio would almost be the same. I am unable to tell him why or where the difference is in the example he quoted, unless he gives me more specific details. If he really wants to know why it is so, perhaps he can get the information by sending in a Question for Oral Answer.

Column: 1436



    Finally, he wants to know why the Building Control Division gives notice to a congregation of people who say prayers in the morning in a residential area. As I have said, in a small island like Singapore where there is hardly any elbow room, we have to be very careful about the usage of land. I do not know whether the Member would like to have a Chinese wayang playing every morning next to his house. He shook his head. He does not like it. Similarly, when a congregation of people meet every morning in a residential area, they are bound to create some sort of nuisance. Therefore, probably complaints have been received from neighbours, and that is the reason why notice has been given to them to stop meeting in the morning for prayers in a residential area. We are very careful about illegal use.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. The house owner is praying inside his house. What is the objection of the Building Control Division? The people are praying inside the house. What is the objection of the Building Control Division and why must they stop it? There is also discrimination because nobody disturbs the other houses where praying is also being conducted. There are so many other places where there is praying. They are not disturbed. This is the only place where they come and disturb. What is the reason for that? That is discrimination, is it not? There must be equal treatment.

    An hon. Member: Victimisation.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Victimisation.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not single any person or any group of persons to victimise them. I do not know the case. For all I know, it may be in a very quiet residential area. If the house owner concerned has got permission for use as a prayer house, the Building Control Division will not disturb him. However, I am speaking "in the dark". He has not given me the address. Unless he gives me the details of the house concerned, I am unable at this moment to tell him whether or not permission has been given for its use as a prayer house or whether it is in a zone for

Column: 1437

places of worship. But if he wants further clarification, then let him send in a Question for Oral Answer.

    I hope Members will appreciate that it is not possible for me or even for my colleague, the Senior Minister of State, or for any Minister, to be able to give in detail specific replies to specific questions. We are only able to tell Members generally the kind of policy that we pursue. But when Members bring up specific instances, it is beyond us to give a detailed reply there and then. Perhaps some of the queries which have been raised during this debate by hon. Members from time to time could best be answered through written Questions for Oral Answer. This is one of them. However, if the Member will give me further details, I might be able to satisfy him as to why notice was given.

    The Member for Potong Pasir has again raised the question of the missing clauses. We have taken up his suggestion and we are in consultation with the experts in the Labour Ministry. We hope to solve the problem soon by including the necessary clauses in the new regulations.

    Haji Sha'ari Bin Tadin: Mr Speaker, Sir, before withdrawing my amendment, I would just like to complete my sentence just now when you cut me off, so that the sentence would not be left hanging - "I hope a similar situation will not happen to residents in Neighbourhood II and other Neighbourhoods in the New Town." Since the Minister has given a satisfactory reply and an assurance that this thing will not happen, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead BAA 1101*. (* The same amendment also stood in the names of Messrs Ng Kah Ting and Teo Chong Tee).

    Mr Speaker, Sir, for the last few years I have spoken about the favourite hobby of certain departments, that is the digging of roads. Even today we still find many roads

Column: 1438

being dug, filled up, re-dug, filled up, and re-dug, so much so that some roads seem to be in perpetual disrepair. Is the co-ordinating body really working to make sure that all necessary excavations and repairs are done at the same time? It also appears that when the roads are levelled up, the workmanship and materials seem to be poor. Very often we find that the gravel come loose particularly after a heavy rain. Therefore, the material and workmanship should be properly checked by the authorities. Whether or not they check them, God knows.

    We see that many traffic circuses at road junctions, like the ones at Tanglin, MacRitchie, etc, are being converted into traffic light controlled intersections. Why were these circuses constructed in the first place? Do these conversions help in any way to alleviate traffic jams?

3.15 p.m.

    Sir, take MacRitchie circus as an example. The removal of the circus has not solved the traffic jams; worse still, it has become a dangerous accident-prone area. Lately, many people were seriously injured or killed at that place because of accidents. When there was a circus, there were no accidents. Since removal of the circus, many accidents occurred resulting in death. Something must be done to make sure that there is proper planning before any modification is made.

    Sir, at Keppel Road which is in my constituency, there is a railway line which runs across the road near the Cold Storage Building. This is an accident-prone area as many serious accidents have occurred there. If one takes a look at the fence along the railway ground which is beside the road, he will see that it has been damaged because of traffic accidents. Another area which seriously needs to be looked into is the bend along Kampong Bahru and Kampong Lama Road. This bend is so narrow that vehicles going up to the Singapore General Hospital are literally running on the five-foot way meant for pedestrians. This five-foot way is

Column: 1439
